facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1324 of 1967 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1324 of 1967.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 31, 1966 of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 344 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 31, 1966 of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 344 of 1966.

facts.text: Appellant is Patiraji.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant Patiraji is entitled to the Adhivasi rights under section 20 b i of the P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1950 the Act .

facts.text: One Ram Adhar and the respondents were co-tenants of certain lands situated at Bibiganj, District Sultanpur.

anchor.surface_text: One Ram Adhar and the respondents were co-tenants of certain lands situated at Bibiganj, District Sultanpur.

facts.text: Ram Adhar died on February 24, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: On the death of Ram Adhar on February 24, 1949 the appellant took proceedings under the U.P. Tenancy Act, 1939

facts.text: Appellant took proceedings under the U.P. Tenancy Act, 1939 for declaration that she was the widow of Ram Adhar and became co-tenant with respondents.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant took proceedings under the U.P. Tenancy Act, 1939 for a declaration that she was the widow of Ram Adhar and as such, had become a co-tenant along with the respondents.

facts.text: Appellant succeeded before the Assistant Collector.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant succeeded before the Assistant Collector but in appeal,

facts.text: Additional Commissioner and Board of Revenue held appellant not the widow of Ram Adhar on July 1, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: but in appeal, the Additional Commissioner and then the Board of Revenue took a contrary view, holding that the appellant was not the widow of Ram Adhar. The judgment of the Board of Revenue is dated July 1, 1954.

facts.text: U.P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1950 came into force on July 1, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: In the meanwhile, the Act had come into force on July 1, 1952.

facts.text: Appellant brought suit under section 20 b read with section 232 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then brought the present suit, treated as one under section 20 b read with section 232 of the Act.

facts.text: Appellant's name was recorded as an occupant in the Khasra of 1356F.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the appellant is that her name was recorded as an occupant in the Khasra of 1356F, that she has therefore become an Adhivasi

facts.text: Appellant claims entitlement to possession as Adhivasi under section 20 b i.

anchor.surface_text: under section 20 b i and is consequently entitled to possession of the lands, from which she was unlawfully dispossessed by the respondents.

facts.text: Appellant was dispossessed by the respondents.

anchor.surface_text: from which she was unlawfully dispossessed by the respondents.

facts.text: Trial court dismissed the suit.

anchor.surface_text: The trial court dismissed the suit but the Additional Commissioner

facts.text: Additional Commissioner allowed appellant's appeal and decreed the suit.

anchor.surface_text: but the Additional Commissioner allowed Patirajis appeal and decreed her suit.

facts.text: Board of Revenue dismissed respondents' appeal against Additional Commissioner's decision.

anchor.surface_text: Respondents carried an appeal against the decision of the Additional Commissioner to the Board of Revenue but that appeal was dismissed.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court single judge allowed respondents' writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents then filed a writ petition in the High Court of Allahabad, which was allowed by a learned single Judge of that court.

facts.text: Single judge held entry in Khasra 1356F for appellant was for part of the year only, not entitling to Adhivasi rights.

anchor.surface_text: He held that the entry in favour of the appellant appeared in the Khasra of 1356F for a part of the year only and therefore she was not entitled to the Adhivasi rights.

facts.text: Division Bench of Allahabad High Court dismissed Special Appeal No. 344 of 1966 in limine on October 31, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Special Appeal No. 344 of 1966 against the judgment was dismissed by a Division Bench in limine on October 31, 1966.

facts.text: Khasra 1356F entry: Ram Adhar Pandey Bakasht Waris Baqa biz Smt. Patraji Motwaffi Bewa Ram Adhar Panedy Tarikh 24-2-49 Se.

anchor.surface_text: The sole foundation of the appellants claim is an entry which appears in the Khasra of 1356F, which is to the following effects- Ram Adhar Pandey Bakasht Waris Baqa biz Smt. Patraji Motwaffi Bewa Ram Adhar Panedy Tarikh 24-2-49 Se,

facts.text: Entry indicates Smt. Patiraji in possession as heir widow from 24-2-49.

anchor.surface_text: that is to say Ram Adhar Pande in cultivation heir in possession Smt. Patiraji widow of deceased Ram Adhar Pandey from 24-2-49.

facts.text: Board of Revenue erred in assuming appellant was sole heir of Ram Adhar.

anchor.surface_text: It would seem that the Board of Revenue struck a discordant note in the instant case only, but it is necessary to point out that the Board rested its decision on the circumstance that the appellant was the sole heir of Ram Adhar.

facts.text: Earlier proceedings held appellant was not the widow of Ram Adhar.

anchor.surface_text: In making that assumption the Board was in error, because in the earlier proceedings it was held that the appellant was not the widow of Ram Adhar

facts.text: Appellant traced no other line of heirship.

anchor.surface_text: and she traced no other line of heirship.

arguments.claim: Appellant Patiraji is entitled to Adhivasi rights under section 20(b)(i) as her name was recorded as an occupant in the Khasra of 1356F

holdings.text: the Adhivasi rights can be claimed by those persons only who are recorded as occupants for the whole of the Fasli year 1356

anchor.surface_text: Looking at the provision contained in section 20 b i , it seems to us plain that the Adhivasi rights can be claimed by those persons only who are recorded as occupants for the whole of the Fasli year 1356.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain language of section 20(b)(i) requires recording as occupant throughout the Fasli year 1356; confirmed by Khasra preparation process and uniform precedent

holdings.text: there is, in the first instance, no justification for construing the provision with greater liberality than the language warrants. Special rights conferred by the Act ought to be subject to the special limitations imposed by the Act

anchor.surface_text: Clearly therefore, there is, in the first instance, no justification for construing the provision with greater liberality than the language warrants. Special rights conferred by the Act ought to be subject to the special limitations imposed by the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Literal interpretation required as provision confers special rights even on trespassers

holdings.text: any other view of section 20 b i would make it unworkable in practice and would set the pace for lawlessness amongst trespassers

anchor.surface_text: Apart from this aspect, any other view of section 20 b i would make it unworkable in practice and would set the pace for lawlessness amongst trespassers. If different persons are in occupation of a land during different parts of the year,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Multiple part-year occupants from tri-annual inspections would create chaos in determining Adhivasi

holdings.text: there is neither logic nor good sense in such a course [of recognising the last entry-holder as an occupant to the exclusion of others]

anchor.surface_text: It was urged that the last entry-holder Should be recognised as an occupant ,to the exclusion of others but there is neither logic nor good sense in such a course. The last holder may have been in possession for a fractional part of the year

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fractional possession may coincide with inspection; would encourage trespassers to vie for last position

holdings.text: the right conferred by section 20 b i can be availed of by those persons only who are recorded as occupants for the entire Fasli year 1356 and not by those who are recorded as occupants for a part of the year

anchor.surface_text: Rightly therefore, the High Court of Allahabad and the Board of Revenue, U.P. have been uniformly taking the view that the right conferred by section 20 b i can be availed of by those persons only who are recorded as occupants for the entire Fasli year 1356 and not by those who are recorded as occupants for a part of the year.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Uniform interpretation by Allahabad High Court and Board of Revenue in cited cases

holdings.text: the appellant Patiraji is [not] entitled to the Adhivasi rights under section 20 b i of the P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1950

anchor.surface_text: The question which arises for consideration in this appeal is whether the appellant Patiraji is entitled to the Adhivasi rights under section 20 b i of the P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1950 the Act .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Entry in Khasra 1356F only for part of year; does not satisfy whole-year requirement under s.20(b)(i)

holdings.text: the Board was in error [in assuming appellant was the sole heir of Ram Adhar], because in the earlier proceedings it was held that the appellant was not the widow of Ram Adhar and she traced no other line of heirship

anchor.surface_text: It would seem that the Board of Revenue struck a discordant note in the instant case only, but it is necessary to point out that the Board rested its decision on the circumstance that the appellant was the sole heir of Ram Adhar. In making that assumption the Board was in error, because in the earlier proceedings it was held that the appellant was not the widow of Ram Adhar and she traced no other line of heirship.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Bound by earlier proceedings under U.P. Tenancy Act holding appellant not widow; no alternative heirship

It is important to remember that the rights companferred by section 20  b   i  are available even and mostly to trespassers. Clearly therefore, there is, in the first instance, numberjustification for companystruing the provision with greater liberality than the language warrants.

anchor.surface_text: It was urged that the last entry-holder Should be recognised as an occupant ,to the exclusion of others but there is neither logic nor good sense in such a course. The last holder may have been in possession for a fractional part of the year

Looking at the provision companysained in section 20 b   i , it seems to us plain that the Adhivasi rights can be claimed by those persons only who are recorded as occupants for the whole of the Fasli year 1356. It is important to remember that the rights companferred by section 20  b   i  are available even and mostly to trespassers. Clearly therefore, there is, in the first instance, numberjustification for companystruing the provision with greater liberality than the language warrants.

edges.explanation: The holding directly resolves the issue by stating that the appellant is not entitled to the specified rights, matching the exact question posed in the issue.

anchor.surface_text: The question which arises for consideration in this appeal is whether the appellant Patiraji is entitled to the Adhivasi rights under section 20 b i of the P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1950 the Act .

Looking at the provision companysained in section 20 b   i , it seems to us plain that the Adhivasi rights can be claimed by those persons only who are recorded as occupants for the whole of the Fasli year 1356. It is important to remember that the rights companferred by section 20  b   i  are available even and mostly to trespassers. Clearly therefore, there is, in the first instance, numberjustification for companystruing the provision with greater liberality than the language warrants.

edges.explanation: Holding critiques assumption of appellant as sole heir based on widow status, directly addressing the issue

anchor.surface_text: It would seem that the Board of Revenue struck a discordant note in the instant case only, but it is necessary to point out that the Board rested its decision on the circumstance that the appellant was the sole heir of Ram Adhar. In making that assumption the Board was in error, because in the earlier proceedings it was held that the appellant was not the widow of Ram Adhar and she traced no other line of heirship.
